newsitem.title: USA: Fed to issue revised U.S. industrial output data.
newsitem.headline: Fed to issue revised U.S. industrial output data.

text.p: The Federal Reserve will issue revisions on Monday to its measures of industrial production and capacity utilization dating back to 1977, partly to better reflect cheaper computer costs.
The Fed said the revisions, to be issued at 1200 EST/1700 GMT, will use updated source data for recent years and also feature a changed method for calculating the indexes.

The impact will be to "slow capacity growth as well as industrial production growth," the Fed said, so the effect on overall capacity utilization -- the gauge of how busy companies were in any single month or year -- should be small.
The Fed said that updating the weights used to calculate industrial production only at five-year intervals failed to capture big changes in the computer industry.

"Because of the rapid fall in the relative price of computers and peripheral equipment, the periodic updating of weights is too infrequent to provide reliable estimates of current changes in output, capacity and capacity utilization," the Fed said.

It added "more frequent updating of the relative price of the output of the computer industry could lower overall industrial production growth in some years by as much as 1/2 percentage point; in other years, the updating of weights will have virtually no effect."
